pr_title: Update github administration page to reflect current discussion

timeline.message: update administrative rules surrounding PRs (from our discussion)

timeline.bodyText:
I suggest an additional point:
  • If there is a review requesting changes, but the author and the reviewer cannot resolve their dispute, then ????????
    • Note: I write question marks since I'm not sure how this should be handled. I agree with @rhwood that some PRs should never be merged, for different reasons, but I'm also concerned if a single reviewer can veto a PR that the rest of us wants to be merged.
timeline.author: danielb987
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -46,20 +46,41 @@

Merging a PR

- - Except in exceptional circumstances (which should probably be discussed in the PR itself), - PRs should only be merged when: + + JMRI's Github is configured with the following automations and requirements for merging a Pull Request:
    -
  • They have passed all the CI tests
    • -
  • They have no outstanding reviews
    • -
  • If in a new area, large or from a new contributor, - they have been in-queue for at least a day or so to allow people to take a look at them
    • -
  • Don't appear to have any un-resolved controversies in the comments
    • +
  • All CI tests have passed for the Pull Request
    • +
  • There has been at least one review from a JMRI developer that accepts the Pull Request
    • +
  • There are no reviews requesting changes

timeline.bodyText: request adding "nor increase the workload of developers  nor is a incomplete change to structure or practice that will require future work by others." (Maybe that should be a bulleted list instead of a run-on sentence).

If you want a bit more time before somebody merges a PR, either start a review saying that or set "WIP" in the title while explaining why in a comment. +

+ When reviewing a pull request, the focus should be on function and not style. The following should be + considered when reviewing a pull request. +

    +
  • Does the Pull Request add something positive to JMRI. This may include, but is not limited to: +
      +
    • New features
      • +
    • Fixing issues in existing code
      • +
    • Improve some the development or CI process
      • +
    +
    • +
  • Does the Pull Request function as described by the author.
    • +
  • Except in rare circumstances, which must be discussed in the PR, the PR does not + remove existing features from JMRI

timeline.bodyText: Is "must be discussed in the PR" sufficient?  or should that be "should have been discussed on the jmri-users list in advance, or at least before the PR is merged"? Particularly big things should be discussed preferably before the work is put in to create them, to deconflict discussions about whether they should be merged.
